common.clinicalInfoDescription: This page provides educational information. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

depression.clinicalDisclaimer: This page provides educational information about depression. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

whatIs.title: What is Depression?
whatIs.p1: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a common but serious mood disorder that affects how you feel, think, and handle daily activities. It's characterized by persistent sadness and loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities.
whatIs.p2: Depression affects approximately 21 million adults in the United States, making it one of the most common mental health conditions. The good news: depression is highly treatable with therapy, medication, or a combination of both.

list: Loss of interest or pleasure in hobbies and activities
Difficulty concentrating, remembering, or making decisions
Changes in sleep patterns (insomnia or oversleeping)
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
symptoms.conclusion: If you experience five or more of these symptoms for at least two weeks, consult a mental health professional for evaluation.

psychotherapy.title: Psychotherapy
psychotherapy.cbt: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Helps identify and change negative thought patterns
psychotherapy.ipt: Interpersonal Therapy (IPT): Focuses on improving relationships and social functioning
psychotherapy.ba: Behavioral Activation: Increases engagement in positive activities

medication.title: Medication
medication.ssris: SSRIs: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (e.g., fluoxetine, sertraline)
medication.snris: SNRIs: Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (e.g., venlafaxine, duloxetine)

lifestyle.title: Lifestyle Modifications
list: Regular exercise (30 minutes, 3-5 times per week)

medicationDetails.title: Medication Management & Side Effects
medicationDetails.intro: Antidepressant medications are often effective for moderate to severe depression. They work by adjusting neurotransmitter levels in the brain.
importantNotes: Medications typically take 4-6 weeks to show full effects
Never stop antidepressants abruptly (risk of discontinuation syndrome)
Work closely with your prescriber to find the right medication and dosage
Report any concerning side effects immediately

resources.nimh: National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) - Depression
resources.nami: National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) - Depression

anxiety.clinicalDisclaimer: This page provides educational information about anxiety disorders. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

whatIs.title: What are Anxiety Disorders?
whatIs.p1: Anxiety disorders are the most common mental health conditions in the United States, affecting approximately 40 million adults. While everyone experiences anxiety from time to time, anxiety disorders involve persistent, excessive worry that interferes with daily activities.
whatIs.p2: Anxiety disorders include generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, and specific phobias. The good news: anxiety disorders are highly treatable with therapy, medication, or a combination of both.

symptoms.intro: Symptoms of anxiety disorders may include:
list: Excessive worry or fear that's difficult to control
Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
Panic attacks (sudden intense fear with physical symptoms)
Avoidance of situations that trigger anxiety
Physical symptoms: rapid heartbeat, sweating, trembling, shortness of breath
symptoms.conclusion: If anxiety significantly impacts your daily life, relationships, or work, consider consulting a mental health professional.

gad.title: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
gad.description: Persistent, excessive worry about various aspects of daily life (work, health, relationships) lasting at least 6 months.

panic.title: Panic Disorder
panic.description: Recurrent unexpected panic attacks—sudden episodes of intense fear accompanied by physical symptoms like rapid heartbeat, sweating, and chest pain.

social.title: Social Anxiety Disorder
social.description: Intense fear of social situations where you might be judged, embarrassed, or scrutinized by others.

phobias.title: Specific Phobias
phobias.description: Excessive fear of specific objects or situations (e.g., heights, flying, animals) that leads to avoidance behavior.

psychotherapy.title: Psychotherapy
psychotherapy.cbt: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Helps identify and challenge anxious thoughts
psychotherapy.exposure: Exposure Therapy: Gradual, controlled exposure to feared situations
psychotherapy.act: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT): Learning to accept anxiety while pursuing valued goals
psychotherapy.relaxation: Relaxation Techniques: Deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, mindfulness

medication.title: Medication
medication.snris: SNRIs: Effective for GAD (e.g., venlafaxine, duloxetine)
medication.betaBlockers: Beta-blockers: For performance anxiety and physical symptoms

medicationDetails.title: Medication Management
medicationDetails.intro: Medications for anxiety work by affecting neurotransmitters in the brain that regulate mood and stress responses.
considerations: SSRIs/SNRIs: Take 4-6 weeks for full effect; first-line for long-term management
Benzodiazepines: Fast-acting but only for short-term use due to dependency risk
Buspirone: Non-addictive but takes several weeks to work
Beta-blockers: Helpful for situational anxiety (e.g., public speaking)
medicationDetails.conclusion: Work with your healthcare provider to find the most effective medication with minimal side effects. Never stop medication abruptly without medical supervision.

resources.nimh: National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) - Anxiety Disorders
resources.adaa: Anxiety and Depression Association of America (ADAA)

adhd.clinicalDisclaimer: This page provides educational information about ADHD. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

whatIs.title: What is ADHD?
whatIs.p1: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a neurodevelopmental condition characterized by persistent patterns of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. While often diagnosed in childhood, many adults continue to experience symptoms that impact work, relationships, and daily functioning.
whatIs.p2: ADHD affects executive functions—the brain's ability to plan, organize, focus, and regulate emotions. With proper treatment including medication, therapy, and behavioral strategies, individuals with ADHD can thrive and achieve their goals.

inattention: Difficulty organizing tasks and managing time
Avoiding tasks that require sustained mental effort
hyperactivity: Restlessness or feeling driven by a motor
symptoms.conclusion: ADHD presents differently in adults than children, often with less visible hyperactivity and more internal restlessness and executive function challenges.

medication.title: Medication
medication.stimulants: Stimulants: Methylphenidate (Ritalin, Concerta) and amphetamines (Adderall, Vyvanse)—most effective for symptom management
medication.nonStimulants: Non-stimulants: Atomoxetine (Strattera), guanfacine, clonidine—alternative options with different side effect profiles

behavioral.title: Behavioral Strategies
behavioral.skills: Organizational skills training: Time management, task prioritization, calendar systems
behavioral.cbt: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Addressing negative thought patterns and procrastination
behavioral.coaching: ADHD coaching: Accountability and skill-building support
behavioral.routines: Structured routines: Creating predictable daily schedules

lifestyle.title: Lifestyle Modifications
list: Consistent sleep schedule (ADHD often co-occurs with sleep disorders)
Breaking large tasks into smaller, manageable steps

medicationDetails.stimulantsIntro: Stimulants increase dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain, improving focus, impulse control, and executive function. They work quickly (often within 30-60 minutes) and are highly effective for 70-80% of people with ADHD.
sideEffects: Increased heart rate or blood pressure (requires monitoring)
medicationDetails.nonStimulantsIntro: Non-stimulants like atomoxetine take longer to work (several weeks) but provide 24-hour coverage and have lower abuse potential. They may be preferred for people with anxiety, substance use history, or cardiovascular concerns.
considerations: Medication is most effective when combined with behavioral strategies
Finding the right medication and dose may take time and adjustment
Regular follow-ups with your prescriber are essential
Stimulants are controlled substances; follow prescription guidelines carefully

livingWith.title: Living with ADHD
timeManagement: Digital calendars with alerts and reminders

resources.chadd: Children and Adults with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (CHADD)
resources.nimh: National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) - ADHD

bipolar.clinicalDisclaimer: This page provides educational information about bipolar disorder. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

whatIs.title: What is Bipolar Disorder?
whatIs.p1: Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition characterized by extreme mood swings that include emotional highs (mania or hypomania) and lows (depression). These mood episodes can affect sleep, energy, activity levels, judgment, behavior, and the ability to think clearly.
whatIs.p2: Bipolar I Disorder involves at least one manic episode that may be preceded or followed by hypomanic or major depressive episodes. Bipolar II Disorder involves at least one major depressive episode and at least one hypomanic episode, but no full manic episodes.
whatIs.p3: Bipolar disorder is a lifelong condition that requires ongoing treatment, but with proper management including medication, therapy, and lifestyle modifications, people with bipolar disorder can lead fulfilling, productive lives.

mania: Decreased need for sleep (feeling rested after 3 hours)
Engaging in risky behaviors (spending sprees, reckless driving, impulsive decisions)
symptoms.hypomaniaDescription: Similar to mania but less severe and shorter duration (at least 4 days). Functioning is not as severely impaired, and there are no psychotic features.
depression: Persistent sad, empty, or hopeless mood
Significant weight changes or appetite changes

medication.title: Medication (Primary Treatment)
list: Combination Therapy: Often requires multiple medications for optimal control

psychotherapy.title: Psychotherapy
list: Psychoeducation: Understanding bipolar disorder, recognizing early warning signs
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Identifying triggers, developing coping strategies
Interpersonal and Social Rhythm Therapy (IPSRT): Stabilizing daily routines and sleep

lifestyle.title: Lifestyle Management
list: Consistent sleep-wake schedule (critical for mood stability)
Mood tracking and early warning sign monitoring

medicationDetails.lithium: Lithium: Gold standard for bipolar treatment. Requires regular blood level monitoring to ensure therapeutic range and prevent toxicity. Side effects may include tremor, weight gain, increased thirst and urination.
medicationDetails.lamotrigine: Lamotrigine: Particularly effective for bipolar depression. Requires slow titration to minimize rash risk. Generally well-tolerated.
medicationDetails.atypicalIntro: Effective for treating acute mania and preventing relapse. Common side effects include weight gain, metabolic changes (monitor blood sugar and lipids), and sedation.
considerations: Medication adherence is critical; stopping medication often leads to relapse
Regular blood work and monitoring required for many bipolar medications
Antidepressants alone can trigger mania; always use with mood stabilizer if prescribed
Pregnancy planning requires specialized care due to medication considerations
Work closely with a psychiatrist experienced in treating bipolar disorder

crisisManagement.title: Crisis Management & Warning Signs
depressionWarnings: Increased sleep or difficulty getting out of bed
Loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities
emergencySigns: Thoughts of harming yourself or others
Severe agitation or inability to care for yourself
crisisManagement.conclusion: Developing a crisis plan with your treatment team and loved ones can help identify early warning signs and intervene before episodes become severe.

resources.nimh: National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) - Bipolar Disorder
resources.nami: National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) - Bipolar Disorder

ptsd.clinicalDisclaimer: This page provides educational information about PTSD. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

whatIs.title: What is PTSD?
whatIs.p1: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition that can develop after experiencing or witnessing a traumatic event. Traumatic events may include combat, natural disasters, serious accidents, physical or sexual assault, or any life-threatening situation.
whatIs.p2: PTSD is not a sign of weakness—it's a normal response to abnormal and overwhelming circumstances. The brain's natural stress response becomes disrupted after trauma, leading to persistent symptoms that interfere with daily life. With proper treatment, recovery is possible, and many people with PTSD go on to heal and thrive.

symptoms.intro: PTSD symptoms typically begin within 3 months of the traumatic event but may appear later. Symptoms must last more than one month and be severe enough to interfere with relationships or work.
reexperiencing: Severe emotional distress when reminded of trauma
Physical reactions to trauma reminders (sweating, rapid heartbeat)
avoidance: Avoiding thoughts, feelings, or conversations about the trauma
Avoiding people, places, or activities that trigger memories
Difficulty remembering important aspects of the traumatic event
symptoms.negativeChangesTitle: Negative Changes in Thinking and Mood:
negativeChanges: Negative beliefs about oneself, others, or the world
Persistent negative emotions (fear, horror, anger, guilt, shame)
Loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities

traumaTherapy.title: Trauma-Focused Psychotherapy (Most Effective):
list: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT): Helps process the trauma and challenge unhelpful beliefs about the traumatic event
Prolonged Exposure (PE): Gradual, repeated exposure to trauma memories and reminders in a safe, controlled way to reduce fear response
Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR): Processes traumatic memories using bilateral stimulation (eye movements, taps, sounds)
Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT): Combines CBT techniques with trauma-specific interventions

medication.title: Medication:
list: SSRIs: Sertraline (Zoloft) and paroxetine (Paxil) are FDA-approved for PTSD
Prazosin: Can reduce nightmares and improve sleep
Medication is often used alongside therapy for optimal results

complementary.title: Complementary Approaches:
list: Support groups with other trauma survivors
Service animals for veterans with PTSD

traumaInformedCare.title: Trauma-Informed Care Principles
traumaInformedCare.intro: Effective PTSD treatment follows trauma-informed care principles that prioritize safety, choice, and empowerment:
safetyFirst: Creating physical and emotional safety before processing trauma memories
Establishing coping skills and crisis plans
Ensuring current safety (domestic violence, self-harm risks addressed)
clientControl: You control the pace and depth of trauma disclosure
No pressure to share details you're not ready to discuss
You can pause or stop at any time during therapy
stabilization: Addressing substance use, self-harm, or safety concerns
Only when stable will trauma-focused work begin

medicationDetails.ssrisIntro: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors can help reduce PTSD symptoms including intrusive thoughts, avoidance, negative mood, and hyperarousal. They take 4-6 weeks to reach full effectiveness.
medicationDetails.prazosinIntro: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker that can significantly reduce PTSD-related nightmares and improve sleep quality. It's taken before bedtime and may require dose adjustment.
avoidList: Benzodiazepines: Not recommended for PTSD as they can interfere with trauma processing and have addiction potential
Long-term use of sleep medications without addressing underlying trauma
considerations: Medication alone is less effective than therapy alone for PTSD
Combination of medication and trauma-focused therapy is often most effective
Work with a psychiatrist experienced in treating trauma
Regular monitoring for side effects and treatment response

resources.va: National Center for PTSD (U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs)
resources.nimh: National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) - PTSD
resources.istss: International Society for Traumatic Stress Studies (ISTSS)
resources.rainn: RAINN (Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network) - For sexual assault survivors
